Comprehensive portfolio covering PCB design with NE555 timer circuits, control systems analysis, PLC programming, mechanical engineering calculations, and Python data analysis

## Overview This AIS4003 Fundamentals of Automation and Mechatronics Engineering portfolio demonstrates foundational skills across the core disciplines of mechatronics: electronics design, mechanical engineering, control systems, industrial automation, and programming. The portfolio is divided into three main modules with both individual and group work. ## Module I: Mechatronics (Electronics Design) ### PCB Design - NE555 Audio Generator Designed and manufactured a printed circuit board featuring the NE555 timer IC in astable mode for audio signal generation. The circuit includes: - **NE555 Timer IC** - Configured as astable oscillator - **L7809CV Voltage Regulator** - 9V regulated output - **470kÎ© Potentiometer** - Frequency adjustment - **Audio Output** - 3.5mm stereo jack and miniature speaker | Component | Value | Purpose | |-----------|-------|---------| | NE555P | Timer IC | Square wave generation | | L7809CV | Regulator | 9V supply regulation | | Capacitors | 100ÂµF, 100nF, 10nF | Filtering and timing | | Potentiometer | 470kÎ© | Frequency control | | Resistors | 500Î©, 3kÎ©, 4.7kÎ©, 10kÎ©, 15kÎ© | Bias and current limiting | The design was created in Autodesk Fusion 360, with Gerber and drill files generated for PCB manufacturing. The board was then soldered and tested successfully. ## Module II: Mechanical Engineering ### Robot Arm Design Project Complete pick-and-place robot arm design including: - **DH Parameter Tables** - Forward kinematics modeling - **Inverse Kinematics** - Position to joint angle conversion - **Torque Calculations** - Motor sizing for each joint - **Deflection Analysis** - Cantilever beam calculations - **Servo Selection** - eRob 80T and 90T servos chosen Key specifications calculated: - Link lengths: L1 = L2 = 400mm - Workspace: 400mm Ã— 500mm - Joint 1 Torque: 116.56 Nm - Joint 2 Torque: 87.44 Nm - Total deflection: 0.2mm (within tolerance) ### Mechanical Engineering Exercises - Stress and strain calculations for robot arm components - Mass moment of inertia calculations - Gear ratio optimization for servo motors - Encoder resolution requirements ## Module III: Automation and Computer Science ### Control Systems Analysis Derived transfer functions for DC motor model: The differential equation for the motor system: $$J\dot{\omega}_m(t) = -\left(D_m + \frac{K_t K_b}{R_a}\right)\omega_m(t) + \frac{K_t}{R_a}e_a(t)$$ Applied Laplace transform to obtain transfer function relating armature voltage to angular velocity. ### PLC Programming Portfolio Industrial control systems exercises covering: - Ladder logic programming - Sequential function charts - Industrial automation scenarios ### Python Data Analysis Weather data analysis using Python with pandas: - Temperature analysis from Vigra weather station - Rainfall data processing and visualization - Wind speed statistics and plotting ```python # Sample code structure import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # Load and process weather data df = pd.read_csv('Temperature_vigra.csv') # Analysis and visualization... ``` ## Documentation ðŸ“„ View Complete Portfolio (PDF) ## Key Learnings 1. **PCB Design Workflow** - From schematic to manufactured board 2. **Mechanical System Analysis** - Stress, deflection, and dynamics 3. **Control Theory** - Transfer functions and system modeling 4. **Industrial Automation** - PLC programming fundamentals 5. **Data Analysis** - Python for engineering applications ## Project Files - Gerber and drill files for PCB manufacturing - Fusion 360 schematic and board files - Python scripts for weather analysis - Tarot T18 Octocopter for Water Sampling
Building a heavy-lift UAV platform for autonomous water sampling in maritime research environments

## Overview

The Tarot T18 project focuses on developing a robust octocopter platform capable of autonomous water sampling operations in fjord environments. This heavy-lift drone is designed to replace GPS with Pozyx UWB for precise indoor/GPS-denied positioning.

## Problem Statement

Traditional water sampling in Norwegian fjords requires boats and significant logistics. An autonomous aerial platform can:
- Reduce sampling time from hours to minutes
- Access difficult-to-reach locations
- Provide repeatable, georeferenced sampling points

## System Architecture

The system consists of several integrated components working together:

### Hardware Components

| Component | Specification | Purpose |
|-----------|--------------|---------|
| Frame | Tarot T18 Octocopter | Heavy-lift platform |
| Flight Controller | Pixhawk 4 | Flight management |
| Companion Computer | Jetson Orin Nano | Mission logic & sensors |
| Positioning | Pozyx UWB | GPS-denied navigation |
| Pump | Peristaltic pump | Water sample collection |

### Software Stack

- **ROS2 Humble** - Robot Operating System for inter-process communication
- **PX4 Autopilot** - Flight control firmware
- **MAVLink** - Drone communication protocol
- **Python 3.10** - Mission logic and sensor integration

## Technical Challenges

### Challenge 1: GPIO Voltage Issues

**Problem**: Jetson Orin Nano GPIO pins outputting 0V instead of expected 3.3V

**Solution**: Configured pinmux using Jetson-IO tool to properly enable GPIO functionality

**Outcome**: Achieved reliable 3.3V output for pump control circuitry

### Challenge 2: Indoor Positioning

**Problem**: GPS unavailable in indoor test environments

**Solution**: Integrating Pozyx UWB system with Pixhawk via MAVLink position messages

**Status**: Currently configuring tag-anchor communication protocols

## Current Progress

- [x] Frame assembly and motor mounting
- [x] Flight controller configuration
- [x] Jetson Orin Nano integration
- [x] Basic MAVLink communication
- [ ] Pozyx UWB positioning (in progress)
- [ ] Peristaltic pump control system
- [ ] Autonomous mission planning
- [ ] Field testing

## Next Steps

1. Complete Pozyx UWB configuration and calibration
2. Integrate pump control via MAVLink auxiliary commands
3. Develop autonomous sampling mission logic in ROS2
4. Conduct indoor flight tests at IIR Lab
5. Plan outdoor field testing at fjord location
Modular underwater sampling container system for ROV-based marine research with 3D printing and robotic assembly

## Overview This MMA4002 Design for Automated Manufacturing group project developed a 3D-printed underwater sampling container system for ROV-based marine research. The containers are designed to collect seabed sediments, water samples, minerals, and marine organisms at various ocean depths. The project applied Industry 4.0/5.0 principles, Design for Automated Assembly (DFAA), Lean Manufacturing concepts, and Product Architecture strategies. ## Problem Statement Traditional underwater sampling containers lack customization and are expensive to manufacture. Our solution offers: - **Scalability** - Multiple sizes for different sampling needs - **Modularity** - Interchangeable clips and bracket systems - **Automation** - Robot-friendly assembly design - **Cost-effectiveness** - 3D printed components ## Design Concept ![Underwater sampling concept](/images/projects/underwater-concept.jpg) The system consists of: - **Containers** - Three sizes (small, medium, large) with varying wall thickness for depth rating - **Lid Mechanism** - Twist-open design with integrated sealing - **Clip Variants** - Magnet, twist, and slide mechanisms - **Universal Bracket** - Mounts to ROV or diving equipment ## Technical Specifications ### Material Selection | Material | Properties | Use Case | |----------|-----------|----------| | PETG | Water resistant, durable, easy to print | Container bodies | | TPU | Flexible, watertight | Sealing gaskets | ### Pressure Calculations Wall thickness calculated using thin-wall pressure vessel formula: $$t = \frac{P \cdot D}{2 \cdot S \cdot E}$$ Where: - P = Hydrostatic pressure at depth - D = Container diameter - S = Material tensile strength (PETG: ~50 MPa) - E = Safety factor ### Product Architecture Implemented **Slot Architecture** allowing: - Three container sizes sharing common clip interface - Three clip variants (magnet, twist, slide) - Universal bracket fits all containers ## DFAA Evaluation Design for Automated Assembly principles applied: | Principle | Implementation | |-----------|---------------| | Reduce parts | Minimized to essential components | | Base object | Bracket serves as assembly base | | Assembly directions | Top-down Z-axis assembly | | Self-aligning features | Chamfers and guides for robot grippers | | Unique orientation | Asymmetric features prevent misassembly | ## Manufacturing Workflow 1. **Design Phase** - CAD modeling with customer specifications 2. **Material Selection** - Based on depth requirements 3. **3D Printing** - Automated FDM printing with PETG 4. **Quality Control** - Dimensional inspection 5. **Robot Assembly** - Collaborative robot assembles components 6. **Final Inspection** - Seal integrity testing ## Collaborative Robot Assembly The assembly process uses collaborative robots (cobots) at ManuLab: Assembly sequence: 1. Pick bracket from feeder 2. Attach selected clip variant 3. Install container body 4. Quality verification ## Industry 4.0/5.0 Implementation ### Industry 4.0 Technologies Used - **Additive Manufacturing** - 3D printing for customized production - **Simulation** - CAD analysis before production - **Autonomous Robots** - Cobot assembly ### Industry 5.0 Principles - **Human-centricity** - Design considers diver/operator needs - **Sustainability** - Minimal material waste, recyclable PETG - **Resilience** - Modular design allows quick adaptation ## Documentation ðŸ“„ Design Report (PDF) ðŸ“„ Reflections Document (PDF) ## Team Contribution This was a group project with three team members. My contributions included: - Pressure and wall thickness calculations - DFAA analysis and optimization - 3D modeling iterations - Documentation and technical writing ## Key Learnings 1. **Design for Manufacturing** - Creating products optimized for automated production 2. **Industry 4.0/5.0** - Practical application of smart manufacturing concepts 3. **Lean Principles** - Eliminating waste in design and production 4. **Collaborative Robotics** - Programming cobots for assembly tasks 5. **Product Architecture** - Modular design for product families
